# UITextPosition

**Class**

A position in a text container—that is, an index into the backing string in a text-display view.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor class UITextPosition
```

## Overview

Classes that adopt the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UITextInput] protocol must create custom [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UITextPosition] objects for representing specific locations within the text managed by the class. The text input system uses both these objects and [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UITextRange] objects for communicating text-layout information. There are two reasons for using objects for text positions rather than primitive types such as [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSInteger]:

- Some documents contain nested elements (for example, HTML tags and embedded objects) and you need to track both absolute position and position in the visible text.
- The WebKit framework requires that text indexes and offsets be represented by objects.

The simplest of [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UITextPosition] objects—for example, one used in plain text—might have a single integer property that represents an offset into a string. If you adopt the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UITextInput] protocol, you must create a custom [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UITextRange] subclass as well as a custom [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UITextPosition] subclass.

This class declares no methods of its own.

## Metrics

- **UITextRange**: A range of characters in a text container with a starting index and an ending index in string backing a text-entry object.
- **UITextSelectionRect**: An encapsulation of information about a selected range of text in a document.
